abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project,
            particularly with regard to the physical components, was
            satisfactory. The gas supply derived from the project helped
            the national gas company alleviate the country's energy
            shortage and allowed it to operate the
            Hazira-Bijapur-Jagdishpur pipeline at near capacity. The
            project also considerably improved the environment of Bombay
            and Delhi through increased gas consumption. Following the
            sector policy and institutional development measures taken
            by the government since 1996, the project was instrumental
            in fostering natural gas development. Key lessons learned
            noted improvements to 1) the gas supply by eliminating gas
            flaring; 2) both the quality of operations and their cost
            effectiveness by contracting specialized field service
            companies to perform some of the key field maintenance
            operations; 3) the project's economic viability and
            implementation performance by avoiding delay of the
            co-financing agreements; 4) project performance by using
            technical assistance for on-site managerial and operational
            expertise; 5) offshore oil and gas reserves development by
            developing safety and environmental protection legislation
            and setting up an independent agency to enforce it; 6) a
            more economic allocation of resources by eliminating gas
            price distortions; 7) achieving policy objectives by
            requiring regular consultations between the government and
            the Bank; and 8) restructuring the sector entities by
            requiring that transformed companies be autonomous.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project has four objectives:  (a) to
            eliminate the flaring of associated gas in the Bombay High
            oil field and improve the management of the Bombay High
            reservoir; (b) to reduce energy shortages and improve the
            efficiency of energy use in India's Western Region; (c)
            to promote a greater involvement of the private sector in
            the oil and gas industry in India; and (d) to support the
            Oil and Natural Gas Commission's (ONGC's) efforts
            to improve the safety of its offshore operations and reduce
            the risks to the environment from these operations.  The
            project comprises:  (a) construction of two process
            platforms as well as modifications on existing platforms;
            (b) construction of three submarine gas pipelines; (c)
            expansion of the existing Hazira gas terminal; (d)
            engineering, project management and other implementation
            services; (e) reservoir performance and management studies;
            (f) package of measures required to bring the management of
            the reservoirs of the Bombay High oil field in line with
            industry standards and practices; and (g) measures to
            mitigate environmental risks and enhance the safety of
            ONGC's offshore operations.
